Thanks for the info. Actually, by the time I read your reply I had 
already written something similar to the code you directed me to. I 
looped through one collection and then determined if each item in it 
was in the other collection using the "contains" method. Sounds like 
JUnit could use another overloaded version of assertEquals.

--- In junit@y..., "J. B. Rainsberger" <jbr@d...> wrote:
> > Just do assertEquals on expected and actual collections. The
> > collections all have sensible equals methods
> > 
> > i.e. if the 2 collections are lists they will be equal if they
> > contain the same elements in the same order. If the 2 collections
> > are sets they will be equal if they contain the same elements.
> 
> The only problem with this otherwise great advice is that comparing 
two lists 
> for the same elements, although not at the same indices, does not 
work.
> 
> This has been discussed, I think, to death somewhere on the web. 
Maybe you 
> should look at http://c2.com/cgi/wiki?JavaUnitBestPractices and 
hunt around 
> for something on comparing arrays or some such. There should be 
quite a 
> complete discussion.
> 
> The basic idea is this: write your own custom assertion 
> or "collectionsEquals", but be careful how to handle the 
differences. 
> Especially for big collections, you need an easy way to know what 
the 
> differences are between the collections in the case where they are 
not equal.
> 
> If that resource does not help you, then let us know and we'll fill 
in the 
> blanks. This sounds like another "Tip and Trick" for my site. :)
> 
> --
> J. B. Rainsberger,
> President, Diaspar Software Services
> Let's write software that people understand.
